turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: Exactly.
When the treaty --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, the answer is, suppose you get a brand-new type of fish coming by.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: If that is a natural fish, I think that the Tribe has both to the benefit -- yes, sir.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Suppose somebody makes a fish and puts him in the river.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: If the State creates a new breed of fish, that would have exactly the same rights as the hatchery steelhead do.
The treaty itself --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean the treaty is limited to the fish that ran the river when the time the treaty was made.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: The treaty is limited to the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: At least to their descendants.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: -- natural fish.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And their descendents.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: And their descendents.

Moreover, the treaty includes language that implies this, Mr. Justice Marshall, because the treaty makes it a specific exemption for cultivated shellfish, which was something which was done artificially in 1854, and it excludes from the treaty the only type of marine life which was then cultivated.
So the obvious intention of the treaty would be to treat something new --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But that is what I said: once you exclude one, you are meant to include the others.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: If there was something else to include, Your Honor; but not when that something else did not exist until 1950, 100 years after the treaty was written.

Throughout these entire proceedings, the State has sought to control violations of conservation laws by individual fishermen, and that is exactly the way this Court characterized this case in Puyallup II.
The nature of the case has not changed since that decision.
Individual defendants were involved in Puyallup II and in Puyallup III, once named in the caption of the case.
It was also in Puyallup II and shown by the record to have engaged in fishing activities, as a matter of fact, is present in court here today.

Counsel for other individual members of the tribe who were involved in Puyallup II were served with the initial petition at the beginning of Puyallup III, but failed to appear, evidently feeling that the tribal attorneys and the United States would defend their rights.
No general form of relief was cited in Puyallup III which was not involved in Puyallup I.
We simply seek a definition of the conservation rights which the State has with respect to migratory steelhead and the means by which the State may enforce those rights.
The petition --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Attorne Generla Gorton, may I ask you a question about the hatchery fish that Justice Marshall’s question prompts?
It seems to me there are two quite independent theories which might justify excluding the hatchery fish.
One is that they were not there at the time of the treaty, and then the independent reason is that they were paid for by the license fees.
Would you contend that if the license-fee money had been used to improve water quality in some way which enlarged the run, that a portion of the fish would not be covered by the treaty?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: Enlarged the natural run?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes, enlarged the natural run.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: I would not make that contention.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So it is not the question of where the funds come from; it is a question it is fish that are artificially added, and it does not really matter how they paid for, I guess.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: Well, it is a question of where the funds come from in the sense that these funds were used to create a run, which is an addition.
It is shown by the record to be an addition to the maximum natural run.
If these were simply State funds to improve river quality, no, we would not --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And what if they are simply general-revenue funds that were used to subsidize a new development of a breed of fish or something like that?
You would still say they were excluded.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: Under those circumstances, we would make the same claim.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So the point I am trying to identify is, it is not critical to your argument that there are license fees being used.
The critical point is, it is a brand-new batch of fish.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: It is not critical to my argument.
It might have been to Mr. Willner's.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, I understand.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: He emphasizes that, because he represents the people who may pay those fees.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It might have something to do with his standing to be here, too.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: It may.
We have asked in Puyallup III for a declaratory judgment stating our authority to enforce reasonable conservation regulations upon individual members of the Tribe.
Now, in addition, the Trial Court did grant two elements of limited relief against the tribe itself, and this seems to be the whole basis of the claim that you must dismiss the entire litigation.
First, it required the Tribe to file a list of the names of authorized tribal fishermen, hardly an onerous task; second, that it supply weekly catch figures during the course of the season.

It is really only on the basis of these additional elements of relief that the Tribe seeks dismissal of the entire action on sovereign-immunity grounds, claiming that this is destructive of tribal self-government.

Even if the Court finds that this rather incidental specific ruling is barred by sovereign immunity, it is certainly not precluded from dealing with the merits of the decision which it directed the Washington Supreme Court to make and from affirming the enforcement of those decisions against individual tribal members, it seems to us.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Gorton, do you understand your opponent’s sovereign-immunity contention to be that you simply cannot bring the Tribe into court, the Superior Court of the State of Washington, for whatever purpose or more like an NLRB pre-emption type of thing, where because Federal law such as the Treaty of Madison Creek is involved, a State Court cannot pass on it.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: It is clearly the former, Your Honor, by reason of the argument to which Mr. Willner referred to, that this same counsel are now making in the Ninth Circuit that Federal Courts have no jurisdiction, either.

In other words, in direct defiance of the nine-judge opinion in Puyallup II, it is the essential legal claim of the Tribe that they do have the right to pursue the last living steelhead into their nest and that no court, State or Federal, has any right to interfere with that activity.
So the answer may --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So counsel may concede that the United States could bring a suit against them.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: No, they do not concede that the United States could bring a suit against them.

They concede only that the Congress can change the law; but their position today is that you cannot control their fishery, even if the United States has sued them, and that is exactly what my brother counsel here was reading.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You mean me and my colleagues, I take it.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: No, my colleague here was reading from that brief, I am sorry.
The question of the existence and extent of the reservation has been raised.

I wish to preface my comments on that subject by stating that it has been the consistent position of this Court, and may very well be the strongest single law of the case argument, that the existence or nonexistence or extent of this reservation is simply irrelevant.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Because of perhaps a misapprehension of the Court in Puyallup I, which in the course of its opinion said we do not need to be concerned with the existence or nonexistence of the reservation, because this case involves fishing by Indians off the reservation.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: I think that your decision in Puyallup I, Mr. Justice Stewart, went considerably further than that.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, did the Court say something along those lines in the course of its --

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: It did so, but it also said something else.
It dealt with the fact that the Washington Supreme Court had found the reservation to be terminated and even set out some of the reasons which the Washington Supreme Court utilized.

It then went on to say that you did not need to get to that question, because the only fishing rights which the Puyallup Tribe had were those which it had received under Article III of the treaty, which is the usual and accustomed places in common with all citizens of the territory language.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: And therefore, the implication was, that it did not make any difference; their on-reservation rights and their off-reservation rights were the same.

Now, in the first two cases which this Court considered on this kind of treaty -- remember, there are a dozen or so treaties of Washington and Oregon with similar language, all made in the same year or year-and-a-half period -- dealt with the Yakima Tribe in both the Waynan’s case and the Tuli case.

The treaty in those cases has a separate and explicit exclusive on-reservation fishery right in it, which the Puyallup Treaty does not and which presumably was the reason that Mr. Justice Douglas, writing for this Court in Puyallup I, stated that only Article III was relevant.
Now, the second --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: What was the purpose, since I have already interrupted you, of the first large section of the opinion of the Supreme Court of Washington in this case, giving its view of how the treaty ought to be construed, a view in conflict with other constructions of the other one?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: You effectively have three allocation formulas that are involved with fisheries on the Puyallup at this point.
You have Judge Bolt’s, which has been described here by the Solicitor's Office.
You have the Trial Court's distribution, 45 % to this relative handful of Indian fishermen, 55 % of the natural run to the other citizens of the state, which our Supreme Court has affirmed.
But it affirmed that with a troubled mind.
It felt that it has misled this Court in Puyallup II in indicating that there was any apportionment required at all.
You found in Puyallup II that an apportionment was required, because a non-Indian sports fishery entirely pre-empted the run.
That was not true then, and it is clearly not true in the record now.
The Indians have the right to a sports fishery.
They have a slightly better right than non-Indians, because they need not buy a license for it.
And in fact, they engage in the sports fishery.

So the State Supreme Court is asking you in addition to tell whether or not the language, the right-to-fish language in common with all citizens requires an apportionment at all when there is no discrimination and when the access to and the rights to the fish are the same for the Indian group as they are for the non-Indian group.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And the Court in any case, under its construction of the treaty, no net fishing would be permitted at all by Indians.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: That was, of course, the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But what was the function and purpose of that law, an interesting part of the Supreme Court Washington’s opinion?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: I think in order to persuade you that your decision in Puyallup II was incorrect, because you did not have the facts in front of you.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In Puyallup I.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: No, in Puyallup I, you did not require an apportionment.
It was not until Puyallup II that you required an apportionment.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But that did construe it to allow net fishing, didn’t it?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: I am sorry, I missed your question.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Didn't Puyallup I construe the treaty to allow Indians to fish by net?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: Puyallup I did not construe the treaty in that respect at all --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: -- because the State Supreme Court in Puyallup I had already vacated the Trial Court's judgment on allocation; and so you had no allocation in front of you in Puyallup I, and you quite specifically stated that you were not going to attempt in Puyallup I to say whether an allocation was required.
In Puyallup II, you did so.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You have explained now your understanding of why the Supreme Court of Washington wrote that part of its opinion.
Are you trying to persuade us along the same lines?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: I am, and there is a considerable section of our brief which is devoted very precisely to that argument, because we feel, as the Supreme Court of the State of Washington did, that our record was incomplete and our State Supreme Court made a misstatement in its decision in Puyallup II, which led you to feel that there was discrimination; that only non-Indians could engage in the sports fishery and that therefore an allocation or apportionment was required.
That is simply not the case, and this record shows that not to be the case.
They do, in fact, engage with others in a sports fishery.
The next that I was going to before your series of questions began was the question of the reservation itself.
Now, the question of the reservation itself is a somewhat more narrow one than you have been led to believe by counsel on the other side of this case.
Even if -- we do not concede -- that you cannot even deal with the termination question at all because of what the Ninth Circuit said.
All the Ninth Circuit said was that the reservation had not been terminated.
Inspite of the statements by counsel on the other side, there was no fishing-rights issue in that case whatsoever.
It was solely on whether or not there had been termination.
As it started, there was an alternate claim by the State that there had been determination or diminishment.

The District Court ruled that there had been determination three years ago, the Ninth Circuit reversed and said there had not been determination and sent it back to the Federal District Court in Tacoma.
The United States has not pursued that case -- it does not even have a judgment in it yet -- but it certainly has not pursued any attempt to say what is included within the reservation.
This Court, in Puyallup I, effectively said what is included in the reservation: 22 acres of a cemetery.
Mr. Justice Marshall asked about where the reservation is, and the former or the supposed reservation is shown in a map which is at the back of our brief.

The lines on that map -- unfortunately since it is a transcription of a color map, there is some difficulty with it -- but all the lines that it has lightly cross-hatched is on 18,000 acres which was originally in the reservation back in the middle of the 19th Century.
The heavier lines are the city limits of the City of Tacoma, the City of Fife and there is a portion of the City of Puyallup and other suburban areas within that supposed reservation.
But there has been no determination in the Ninth Circuit that the river is in the reservation or that anything is in the reservation.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the description of the Ninth Circuit opinion in the brief of the United States, it says the Ninth Circuit concluded that the reservation was in existence on Page 5.
As a result, the Court indicated, tribal members had a continuing right to fish free from State interference on that portion of the Puyallup River.
You say that was not a genuine issue in the case?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: That was in the introduction to the Court's opinion.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But it was not an issue.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: But it was not an issue in the case.
Oh, I see.
Excuse me, I am sorry.
The complaint of the United States in the case did raise that issue.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Because --

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: And the quotation in the petitioner’s brief here quotes its complaint in front of the whole --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Because I thought the claim was that the Indian fishing rights were not subject to reconsideration in this case because of decisions in those two other cases.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: Yes, but I think that case, their claim is based most heavily on the decision by Judge Bolt rather than this, because the Ninth Circuit in a very, very short decision simply stated that the reservation had not been terminated.
It did not go into the extent of the reservation; it did not discuss --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, was there a decision on fishing rights or not?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: There has been a decision.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Was there a decision by the Ninth Circuit on fishing rights?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: Yes.
The Ninth Circuit in another case --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, in the case they are talking about.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: No, I do not believe that there was.

There has been in the case in the appeal from the decision by Judge Bolt; but in that decision, of course, Judge Bolt had specifically reserved the question of whether or not hatchery fish were within the treaty rights.
Judge Bolt had the benefit of this Court's decision in Puyallup II before he made his decision.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but he says on the reservation, the State cannot limit their fishing, Judge Bolt.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: I am sorry, whose?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Judge Bolt.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: Oh, okay.
The Bolt cases that came up did not concern itself with on-reservation fisheries.
Judge Bolt has concerned himself from the beginning of this case with off-reservation fisheries.
I am sure that he did make that remark in passing; but all he --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, the United States gives a cite at Page -- job cite to it here that he decided that on-reservation fishing is not subject to State regulation.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: I believe that that is correct that he made such a decision, though that was not a matter which was argued before him; it was not a general subject of that set of proceedings.
Nonetheless, this Court, before he made that decision, remanded this case to the State Courts to make just such determinations, which it has, of course, gone on and done.

Judge Bolt, incidentally, if you read his entire decision, takes the Puyallup I and Puyallup II cases, says in effect that you were wrong, although he gives lip service to following it and uses a totally different apportionment formula than that which you set out in Puyallup II.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And what was the basis of the 45% allocation of the non-hatchery fish?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: I am sorry?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What was the basis of the 45% allocation of the non-hatchery fish?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: I have some difficulty in answering that question precisely.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Was it to protect the Indians or to protect somebody else?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: It would be to protect the Indians, because it would give them a considerably larger percentage of the natural run.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But there may also be a limit on what they could take.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: No.
It was only a limit on what they could take in a net commercial fishery.
It did not limit --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All right, so it was a limit on what they could take by a net commercial fishery.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: By a net commercial fishery.
And the Judge decided that also --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But also an allocation that they could take at least that much.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: At least that much, because they could then go on and take whatever they could get in a sports fishery in common with all of the non-Indian sportsmen.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is de minimis almost to it.
You do not have many Indians, and a sports fisherman gets a steelhead every two or three days at hard fishing, on the average.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: Some of them get better than others, and I think -- well, there may not be a record on this -- I suspect that these professional Indian fishermen are better than the average amateur sportsman; but they will get some.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: That is on here; that is with a good line.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: I do not think it is de minimis.
They have caught some fish in a sports fishery.
It is not a productive use of one’s time from the point of view of hourly pay, however, to fish for steelhead on a hook-and-line basis.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How much riverfront trust property do you suppose there is?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: I do not think there is any.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You mean, the river actually does not run through any property?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: The river is on a new alignment now from what it was at the time the treaty was signed.
It was realigned in the 1920s by the Corps of Engineers.
The trust properly is shown in the record --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, assume the reservation is not in existence.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: If the reservation is not in existence, I do not believe that there is any Indian property or any Indian trust property on the river at all.
The 22 acres are a cemetery, which are located off the river.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: What is this thing between two state highways?
This thing is river?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, the Puyallup River runs in a --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, isn’t this the reservation?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: That is one of the questions, Your Honor.
That is what was the original reservation; but Mr. Justice White’s question to me was, what Indian-owned land or Indian-trust land is there on the banks of the river?
And my answer to that question was, to the best of my knowledge, none.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And how much is that is within the limits here?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: 22 acres, according to Puyallup I, and I think they bought a few acres since the time of that.
2½%of the people who will live within those exterior borders are Indians, and 97½% are non-Indians.
Since I must, in connection with the reservation question, of course, is your decision two weeks ago on the Rosebud case.
We have analyzed the question of the existence of the reservation in connection with the DeCoteau case, which came out after the Ninth Circuit case on this.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What is the State's position with respect to the reservation question, Mr. Attorney General, in terms of whether it was raised in the cite below or whether you conceded it away?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: The question was raised in Puyallup I, was decided by the State Supreme Court in Puyallup I.
The other Federal Court case intervened in that.
We lost that case.
The Trial Court in this case acknowledged what the Ninth Circuit had decided.
I think it resisted; it did not believe that that was a correct decision.
But both the Trial Court decision and the State Supreme Court decision proceeded as if the Ninth Circuit decision on lack of termination was correct.
And we can argue that case here, it was an issue.
It was brought up at both points, and we can raise that issue here only in respect that we have the right to raise any issue which is in the record which would tend to affirm the decision below.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Does that reach issues that were not decided by the State Court?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: No, it reaches an issue which was decided by the --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you did not present that issue to the Washington Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: No, we did not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So, it was neither presented nor decided by the Washington Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: It was presented -- I think that it was presented by the United States in both cases.
It had to be.
They could not have come up with any answer.
They would not have known what had happened under any other circumstances.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If that sounds correct, is there any evidence on it?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: There was not any evidence on it later than Puyallup I; but this is all the same case, of course, as Puyallup I.
Essentially --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I understood you rightfully to say you can use whatever you have to support the judgment.
But you have to have some evidence, don't you?

turn.speaker: slade_gorton
turn.label: Mr. Slade Gorton
turn.text: Oh, I think that if we go to the record in this case, there is evidence on it.
That evidence takes place back in Puyallup I and is the evidence in the decisions of the U.S. District Court and the Court of Appeals.
We feel that this case being here for the third time that all of the issues involved in the decision of the Court are properly before you and that you ought to decide it.
Thank you very much.

section.heading: Rebuttal of William H. Rodgers, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you.
Do you have anything further, Mr. Rodgers?

turn.speaker: william_h_rodgers_jr
turn.label: Mr. William H. Rodgers, Jr.
turn.text: May it please the Court.

In direct response to Mr. Justice White, the position of the State with regard to the reservation question is as follows -- I am reading from Pages 20 and 21 of the Appendix -- we take the position first that we have to operate on the premise that there is a reservation unless the United States Supreme Court ran certiorari on that question and reverses the same, and that question can only be resolved by that format; and the failure to take certiorari or taking so failure to overturn the Ninth Circuit, the reservation is there and we must observe it.
But what we are asking first -- I am reading further to indicate to the Court --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, where are you reading from now?

turn.speaker: william_h_rodgers_jr
turn.label: Mr. William H. Rodgers, Jr.
turn.text: I am reading from the Appendix, Pages 20 and 21, the Joint Appendix, Your Honor.
I am reading further with regard to the natural hatchery issue.

This is from counsel’s opening statement before the Trial Court in Puyallup III: What we are asking first by this Court is to determine that there is a distinction in terms of the treaty right between natively propagated steelhead and those which are hatchery-planted.
Now, that concept, since we only have jurisdiction off-reservation, is only material to the on-reservation fishery.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, it says off-reservation.

turn.speaker: william_h_rodgers_jr
turn.label: Mr. William H. Rodgers, Jr.
turn.text: Excuse me, is only material to the off-reservation fishery.
Here, we have an on-reservation fishery.
The natural hatchery question is not presented.
The entire question of treaty entitlement to hatchery fish is presently pending before Judge Bolt.

My proof on this question, and if I did bring it here was curtailed repeatedly by exclusions of evidence in a nonjury trial dealing with competition between natural and hatchery fish, environmental damage.

For example, the position of the State on this question is that if simply the run were destroyed, the natural run were entirely destroyed and replaced by a hatchery run, then basically there is no more treaty entitlement to that fish.
Secondly, on the sovereign-immunity question, the Attorney General has understated the issue substantially.

Basically on the sovereign-immunity issue, if this Court affirms, you are opening up litigation against a tribe to allocate and apportion its natural resources in State Courts throughout the State of Washington.
The Congress has never permitted such a lawsuit, and I submit that if there is an affirmance on that sovereign-immunity proposition, the effects would be devastating.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But would that not be limited to -- even if we take your assumption, limited to cases where there is an artificial input or artificial --

turn.speaker: william_h_rodgers_jr
turn.label: Mr. William H. Rodgers, Jr.
turn.text: Absolutely not.
Again in response to Mr. Justice White’s question, I believe, the sovereign-immunity defense would apply regardless of the nature of the claim.
They are suing the Tribe, and they have secured orders against the Tribe.
The so-called petty orders include directives to the Tribal Council of the close fisheries under threat of contempt.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, what is allocation now to the Puyallup Indians?

turn.speaker: william_h_rodgers_jr
turn.label: Mr. William H. Rodgers, Jr.
turn.text: The allocation issue is as follows: basically, there is an off-reservation, the Bolt decision indicates a 50/50 allocation question.
The court below allocated on a 45/55 basis; for our purposes, that is insignificant.
There is a further question whether the hatchery fish are excluded.

Presently, under Federal Court order pending adjudication of this entire question in Phase II of United States against Washington, the State is enjoined from excluding hatchery fish from its regulatory activity with regard to all runs, including the Puyallup River.

Now, that meant, again in response to another question, that there indeed is a possibility of Federal/State injunctions, and this Court has looked with a lack of encouragement to that activity, and we have had alternatives and occasionally have gone before the Federal Court to seek injunctive relief.
But on this question, on the question of State power to control on-reservation, we have come up through direct appeals.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Rodgers, at what point in the litigation did you first assert sovereign immunity as a defense?

turn.speaker: william_h_rodgers_jr
turn.label: Mr. William H. Rodgers, Jr.
turn.text: Sovereign immunity, Your Honor, has been asserted in this litigation ever since the case began.
It was rejected in Puyallup I on the premise that we were dealing with an action against individuals off-reservation.
That premise has now dissipated.
It has been urged throughout here and was decided against us on the merits by the Washington State Supreme Court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Of course, that court thought it was doing no more than obeying the order on remand of this Court in Puyallup II.

turn.speaker: william_h_rodgers_jr
turn.label: Mr. William H. Rodgers, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So instead of the wide precedent that you have indicated that affirmance here might mean, really, this is just limited to the Washington Supreme Court’s carrying out what this Court told it to do on remand of this particular and precise case, isn’t it?

turn.speaker: william_h_rodgers_jr
turn.label: Mr. William H. Rodgers, Jr.
turn.text: But to do that, Your Honor, as the concurring opinion below indicates, you have to read Puyallup II as contradicting 150 years of Indian law.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rodgers_jr
turn.label: Mr. William H. Rodgers, Jr.
turn.text: And we believe that you cannot do that.
In conclusion of what --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Rodgers, let me ask you one more question.

I take it if you are right and this sovereign immunity should have been recognized far earlier than now that both of our decisions in Puyallup I and Puyallup II are wiped out, because if the Supreme Court of Washington had no jurisdiction, we surely had no jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: william_h_rodgers_jr
turn.label: Mr. William H. Rodgers, Jr.
turn.text: No, Your Honor, because those cases based upon the premises established -- and indeed, they were facts -- and those cases were off-reservation cases involving individual Indians --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Same case as this case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It is the same, same litigation.
How and where do the facts --

turn.speaker: william_h_rodgers_jr
turn.label: Mr. William H. Rodgers, Jr.
turn.text: Except the reservation now exists, and the orders that initially run against individuals now run against the Tribe.
The Tribal Council, the tribal governing body, its legislative body, has been ordered to enact closures, to enforce closures.
The case has been transformed into an off-reservation individual case into an on-reservation suit against the Tribe itself.
And I would submit in conclusion that the history of this litigation has been determined by one overriding factor, and that is to restrict the Indian fishery.

We have had in this case argued at various times that the tribe is defunct, that the treaty is a worthless scrap of paper, that the reservation does not exist, but that if it does there is power to control as if it did not.
We urge the Court to reverse.
We urge the Court to go further and to dismiss on the ground, we fear, that the slightest ambiguity in its disposition will result in additional litigation.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
